Fields.DialogueText: Ah, Tahiti. The sun, the surf, the supplies...

Fields.MenuText: Corrupting the enlisted, Surcouf?

Fields.DialogueText: Speak.
Miss Surcouf?
Laissez-moi lire ça.
I stole the--
Hmm... sidearms, tampons, oui, double oui... yet another crate of breadfruit...
The crew really like breadfruit.
Have I taught you nothing, mademoiselle? What is the most dangerous thing for an enterprising sailor?
Une habitude, oui. One must sometimes bite one's tongue and learn to like bananas, the better to foster a sense of security in the breadfruit people.
A habit.
Try again.
--secured the goods. They should last us through the month.
Ahem.
Eep!
Ah, and here comes their chief!
You're needed on watch.
Yes, Captain! Sorry, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: I never took you for the tanning type.
Naturally you've set aside a cut for me.

Fields.DialogueText: There are many ways you've never taken me, Capitaine.
Putting them to a practical purpose. Laziness is a seductive foe.
It would be bigger if you turned less of a blind eye.
So are the military police.
Not all handcuffs are created equal.
You're taking it remarkably easy in a recent hot zone.
Oh, it really gnaws at me.
We missed the plague, oui. But I must snatch relaxation where I can in these doldrums. I still have contacts to remind that I exist.
I'm sure the world's mafias will survive without you for another week.
And if they decide they will not? If they send all their fell legions to wrest back their wealth from my capsized hulk?
You have a way of making trouble for yourself. But if you made it, you can unmake it.
Ah, Capitaine, I love you too.
Put down the reflector, would you? It'll draw fire.
Oui, and we are quite warm enough.
@BATTLE
Have the patrols not been to your liking, Capitaine? Perhaps you need a vacation from this vacation?
Until you run out of fuel.
It's too quiet out here.
How lovely to need no sleep! If you think about it, my days are half again as long and productive as yours.

Fields.MenuText: You're certainly doing your best to turn them into one.
I know they're not to yours.
No, it's nice to have a breather. I'm just not used to clear seas these days.

Fields.DialogueText: And how quickly my problems become your problems, non?
Don't I know it.
Leave boredom to those who complain about it, Capitaine. Rest assured I shall find a way to liven up even this forgotten corner of the world.
Please don't get us arrested.
Indicted, Capitaine, but never convicted.
It *has* been a while since we were on a really hectic front.
Fewer and fewer shadows to skulk in...
And not just from the Morganas.
What sort of Belle would I be if I did not keep you on your toes?
A law-abiding one.
Keep it in the bedroom, mon ami.
Très long. Have you any idea how expensive it is to reach my nearest colleagues?
It doesn't go on their prison debt?
Par honte, Capitaine. I run with a higher caliber of human.
Greed *was* in the top half of Hell, as I recall.
Bien. If you are so determined to hunt for a thief, I had heard a rumor about the galley that cigarettes were going missing.
Is that a tip or a confession?
An opportunity, peut-être.
Looking for a partner in crime?
An underling, at best. If our thief were my equal there would be no rumor.
One of you is more than enough to handle.
And don't the Morganas know it. Shall we bat them away and go back to sleep?
@BATTLE
Tais-toi! That is what I am counting on our thief to believe.
A stakeout, is it?
Don't you have better things to do than hide in the ceiling?
Nobody ever looks up.
But you're waiting in a corridor for... what? A pickpocket? Why not leave a pack of smokes under a box propped up on a ruler?
Because I am not trying to attract a rat with a nicotine habit.
This is the most popular area for smoke breaks, Capitaine. There is even an ash tray built into that station there.
If I were to pick the cigarettes from someone's pocket, it would be here, when their guard is at their lowest.

Fields.MenuText: You've never worried about smoking aboard you?
The smell's unbearable.
Wouldn't your crew expect that?

Fields.DialogueText: The crew have a relief watch in case anyone needs a break.
That's not what I was--
Do not interrupt a problem while it is solving itself, Capitaine!
The crew are worse, especially if they happen to run out of soap.
Never teach them *everything* you know.
And how long have you been up there exactly?
Since this morning.
For a thief you're not certain you'll catch.
One hour looks much like another.
That's kind of my point.
What if someone does it during battle?
Industrious souls such as moi are experts at clawing spare time from its deathless march.
I have spent mine teaching the crew to pick pockets, par exemple. The blade itself, and all that.
Bof. Nobody's *that* hard up.
@BATTLE
Silence. You're lucky I didn't try and phase you through a bulkhead.

Fields.MenuText: Surcouf, put him down! You'll choke him out!

Fields.DialogueText: Let's see what's in the paper today...
Morganas. Morganas.
Plague of locusts... oh, that's also Morganas.
Hmm... "Unknown Weapons Seized Following Bar Scuffle..."
Capitaine! We have our culprit!
"The Queen's Ferry bore witness Sunday to a disturbance of the peace when a certain ruffian burst in with--"
Gah! Knock next time, won't you?
And go easy on the collar!

Fields.MenuText: You see the news? Someone's gotten their hands on some weird pistol...

Fields.DialogueText: Save it, Capitaine! Nothing is more important than my hour of victory!
He's destroyed his own lung capacity, Capitaine. Terrible habit, smoking.
Put. Him. Down.

Fields.MenuText: Is that even possible?

Fields.DialogueText: It's not supposed to be. Shall I do the impossible, Capitaine?
Bon.
*THUD* Ow!
Explain yourself.
*sigh* Put him down.
I was just coming back from the galley. Needed a smoke, but I didn't have one on me.
And then the Belle happens by, and she's got that shiny cigarette case. And wouldn't you know it, the alarm went off...
Coquin! Thought I wouldn't notice, did you?
Not that I needed to check. Only one who has not served long in my presence would dare to pickpocket moi.
What's your name, sailor?
Ah, Capitaine, you will not find him in our crew list. We have ourselves a stowaway!
Well, we'll hand him off once we get to Sydney.
Ah, Capitaine... I have never been on the apprehending side before. Why didn't you tell me how exhilarating it is?
Shall we... make the most of this moment?
Surcouf, right here? Right now?
Ne t'inquiètes pas. He can watch.
*ALARM*
Shut up.
Do you two normally--
@BATTLE
Another time, then. To the brig with him?
You should let *me* cook sometime.
Not that. How did we get a stowaway on board?
This doesn't make sense.
Any number of ways, Capitaine. A sous-marine such as myself, with a complement of my size... would it have been so hard to blend in?

Fields.MenuText: Not if he were being aided and abetted.
It shouldn't have been so easy. I should know my crew by now.
What was he even doing?

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps he had an accomplice. Perhaps there sleeps a conspiracy aboard me even now.
Worry not, Capitaine. That is why you have me around.
Swabbing decks, taking watches for one or another obliging shirker... any number of things. Ruffians must be resourceful.
You'd know a thing or two about that, wouldn't you?
Would you have me any other way?
That presents its own set of challenges.
Wouldn't the crew have learned it by watching you?
They would have learned that the thief's first loyalty is to oneself.
Think of it this way, Capitaine. Who better to watch for a criminal than one of their own?
You really came out and said it.
To my accomplice.
You got rid of your leverage on me, remember?
To my willing accomplice.
Don't make me decaffeinate your coffee again.
Do not poison me and I will not poison you.
Romantic.
Isn't it just?
Well, before we get into port I want a full tally of everyone on board. You can detect if you're carrying more people than you ought to.
Oui.
And you'd *tell* me if there were *any more* stowaways aboard, wouldn't you?
Always asking the next question, Capitaine. It is what separates those who have been robbed from those who know they have been robbed.
I don't like your analogies.
You will warm to them, Capitaine. I strive to keep you on the right side of them.
@BATTLE
Prochain!

Fields.MenuText: So far so good.

Fields.DialogueText: Kami-sama.
Name.
Mihara.
Origin.
Position.
Takamatsu, Kagawa Prefecture, Japan.
Fire control.
Bien, dismissed. Prochain!
First Comrade.
Name.
Gumerova.
Origin.
Pavlodar, Kazakh SSR, Soviet Union.
Position.
Torpedoman.
Bien. Prochain!

Fields.MenuText: Wouldn't this be faster if we each took half the crew?
This had better be the end of any stowaway problems.

Fields.DialogueText: If we were preparing for a civil war, peut-être. What I know you must know, et comme ça.
It almost certainly will not be. Everyone wants a piece of me, I fear.
Perhaps the incident was as isolated as we have been these last few weeks.
Don't I wish.
Some of what I know. You know.
They're welcome to try.
Why, Capitaine, I did not know you were that way inclined.
Surcouf!
Oui, oui, oui. Business before pleasure.
Miss Belle?
Oui, oui, oui. Name.
Feldman.
Origin.
... Well, you told me once that one should strive to be mysteri--
*Origin.*
Uh... Queens!
Do you ever worry that you're in too deep?
Definitionally, that is my purpose.
You know what I mean. You tell so many lies that you forget what the truth looks like. Even when it's staring you in the face.
Is that not why we are here now?
Position.
Wherever I am--
*GLARE*
M-midshipman! Woman? Person?
Move along.
When we return, the rest of you may line up just as you are now! I never forget a face.
@BATTLE
Testing my memory, Capitaine.
Wait, I recognize this one. Isn't that Gumerova?
Art project?
Do you think I did her cheekbones justice?

Fields.MenuText: You've got an incredible memory.
She's not *that* gaunt.
It's your test.

Fields.DialogueText: It is a personal exercise, not a wanted poster.
The price of an incredible life. One day you will understand.
And it is your crew, Capitaine. Unless... you have decided to surrender command to moi at last?
I love you too.
You are in my life, you know. I've made sure of it.
Very funny.
Vrai, vrai, as if I would need the formality of rank!
Mhm. And you've decided to wallpaper my quarters with this stuff because?
Immersion, Capitaine! Why do you think I ply the seas so expertly?
Because you're built that way.
Think of me as a shark, Capitaine.
You draw blood if you're rubbed the wrong way?
Lewdness later, mon petit chiot. If I ever stopped moving I would sink to the bottom and perish.
In every glance an analysis; in every step the footwork of a duel.
You may struggle with the identities of your crew now, but they will be indelibly etched into your memory if they are the first and last thing you see each day.
All 120 of them.
All 120-- quoi?
Out of a complement of 118.
... That was a test, Capitaine. You have passed.
Maybe you've been immersed a little too long.
Maybe I planned for you to follow in my wake. You will just have to trust me, non?
I trust you as far as you can shoot...
@BATTLE
And just like that, we are one stowaway lighter.

Fields.MenuText: I'd worry more about the port authority than whatever your friend is up to.

Fields.DialogueText: Only one, eh?
At least someone worried about them.

Fields.MenuText: Stow it.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, I've gotten real good at that, don't you worry.

Fields.MenuText: Trying to see the world for free, eh?

Fields.DialogueText: You might say that. But everything has a price.
Cryptic. You sure he wasn't one of yours, Surcouf?
Why, he is not nearly alluring enough!
So good that you're being handed off.
Half an ocean ain't a bad sprint. But you'll have to run a lot farther to escape what's coming to you.
Worrying is not in my nature, mon coupable. I always have a plan.
Well, we're done with him now.
I still think you should have let me interrogate him. Imagine the secrets I could extract!
Don't you have quite enough of those?
You will never rule over an international empire of commerce with such a lackadaisical attitude, Capitaine.
Look, you turn enough heads without running your own justice system. The least we can do is let the military police do their jobs once in a while.
I suppose not *every* pawn must advance.
You heard what he said, though. We've still got one pawn too many.
Never you mind, Capitaine...
Whenever you say that, I know I should be paying attention.
The problem will solve itself. Our culprit's accomplice has blended in? Bon, we will simply page through the rolls from our previous stops.
An extra name will stick out like a discarded franc. If they disappear into the wilderness of Sydney, so much the better.
You think they will?
Abandon me after a taste of my intrigue? Bien sûr que non. They will deliver themselves to us because I am simply that compelling.
I hate that you're right.
It works for the Morganas, does it not?
Different compulsion.
@BATTLE
Quelle formalité. Call me by my name.
Surcouf, ïä. I've finished sweeping my section of the crew quarters.
First Comrade?
Find anything fascinating?
No sign of anyone extra. Unless they were sharing a cot with someone.
Ah, scandale!
That was my thought. But no sign of that either.
Très bien. You may be about your business.

Fields.MenuText: Surely you would have noticed people doubling up.

Fields.DialogueText: Suis une femme internationale de mystère, not some voyeur.

Fields.MenuText: I talked to Mihara earlier. He's clueless as well.

Fields.DialogueText: A catching disease, it seems. So much the better for the resourceful among us.

Fields.MenuText: What's her business? Bootlegging?

Fields.DialogueText: Not everyone on the crew is so interesting, Capitaine.
Pickpocketing isn't what I call resourceful.
Spoken like a mark.
I've been over and over the rolls. We picked up one Matelot Quirion in Faaa.
I think I would remember a name like that. First name?
Says here... "Fou?"
Fou Quirion... Fou Q.
All right, so we've got a bilingual joker on our hands.
Only most of them.
Besides, she's a devout Muslim. Won't have anything to do with the stuff.
You don't have to drink it to sell it.
You think I didn't tell her that?
More to the point, someone has been lax in their keeping of the lists.
Who's in charge of that?
One Matelot Feldman.
Bring her in. After we chase these Morganas out.
@BATTLE
Have you tried installing an ASDIC? They're terribly convenient.
Your guilty conscience, perhaps.
Gosh, it's dark in here.
Gah! Where did you come from!?
Guilty? I'm not guilty! Whatever it is, I didn't do it, I swear!
It is your duty to keep track of the crew list, is it not?
Well, yeah, but--
And did it not strike you as odd that there were more names than crew?
Well, I don't exactly talk to everyone on the ship--
Fou Q.
I-- what? What was that for?
Does that name mean anything to you?
Oh! Well, I kind of giggled, but I figured maybe it was a coincidence? Like some kind of language thing...
Please don't hurt me?
Oh, I am not going to *hurt* you, Mademoiselle Feldman.
A Belle in my position would like nothing more than to *help.*
For nothing more than negligence, a pretty young lady finds herself on the incorrect side of the law.
And what does she need? Why, some guidance from one practiced in skirting that edge.
Whatever they are paying you, Mademoiselle matelot, I can triple it. Quadruple it. You need not be a pawn.
Nor a queen, honnêtement. But make yourself useful and you need not be so easily sacrificed.
Uh... I don't play chess. Hey, checkers has kings. Is it like that? Uh, you're *really* close...

Fields.MenuText: Sailor, you're not in serious trouble. Galley duty and then you're back to the lists.
Tell the truth, sailor.
Surcouf, she doesn't know anything. Ease up.

Fields.DialogueText: Eep! I mean, thank you, Captain! Won't happen again, Captain!
I swear I don't know anything!
Perhaps our problem is as simple as that. And perhaps not.
Uh-huh! I'm very out of touch!
Then why are you here, except to act according to my whims?
I've heard enough. We'll get to the bottom of this we we have to brute-force it.
Can we do it... without brute force? Please?
Dismissed.
What do you think?
It was not a total waste of my time. She fears me, and that is often the foundation of a fruitful professional relationship.
Is it now.
I know that tone of voice, Capitaine. Does not our relationship cross over into the personal, de temps en temps?
If ever we get a moment free...
@BATTLE
Impossible! I triple-checked the maps, Capitaine. There haven't been Morganas in these waters for weeks!
Looks like they counted on that.
*BOOM*
Stations, yesterday! We walked right into them!
@BATTLE
All right, what happened? Either our intel was way out of date or someone tipped off the Morganas to our route.
I will not dissemble, Capitaine. We were caught unawares.
Yeah, I got that far. Why?
A tormenting question, Capitaine, truly. The only explanation is sabotage.

Fields.MenuText: We're remarkably quick to settle on it.
But by whom?
Or espionage.

Fields.DialogueText: Different names for the same thing, in our line of work. Equally intriguing.
Let's not hand it to them.
Ah, Capitaine, why would I hand anyone anything I could not take back?
Vexing. Our crew's loyalty is not in doubt, Capitaine, I can assure you of this.
The crew that you've bribed and blackmailed.
Handsomely.
What else could it be? You know me for my perfection.
When you've had your coffee.
I said perfection, not godhood.
If there's not a sleeper agent among the crew, the Royal Australian Navy could be compromised. We need to notify Command.
And if the conspiracy goes straight to the top? Non, Capitaine, we solve this ourselves.
Absolutely not. We can't sit on this just because we're paranoid.
And if we do not sit on it, Command will sit on us. I relish a challenge, Capitaine, but I am loath to conduct my usual business in a glass prison of scrutiny.
That sounds like a personal problem.
Which makes it your problem.
... Fine. I'll make some calls. But leave this to me, you understand?
We are a team, are we not?
You're on a few teams, Surcouf, and the sports they play are racketeering, smuggling, and murder.
Allegedly.
Case in point.
A bit arbitrary, non?
You. A moment of your time.
Kanchou?
Where did you go while you were on liberty?
I took a walk on the beach. Never left sight of the port.
What time?
J-just this morning. Before 11.
And the tide?
Low.
Very well. Move along.
Hai, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: No more arbitrary than your interrogation of Feldman.
Do you have any better ideas?
Don't you routinely chide me for not being more involved with the crew?

Fields.DialogueText: Why, I had every reason to speak to her as I did.
Name one.
Anyone *that* hapless must be hiding something. And if they are not, what good fortune for us!
I have contacts aplenty that could investigate the Royal Australian Navy clandestinely.
Look at it this way. If I interrogate everyone at a designated time and place, they know it's coming. A random sample at random intervals throws them off their guard.
Unless they are practiced liars, Capitaine, and then where will you be?
Uh-huh. For how many pounds of flesh?
Well, not *our* flesh.
Only as I would chide a cat for scratching. I am quite comfortable with you walking a step behind me.
Too comfortable.
You spoil me.
Fighting off Morganas with a Belle who claims she doesn't need the help.
And you believe me?
Are you admitting that there are some things you can't do?
Jamais, Capitaine. But I do wish you would leave this matter to me.
As your captain and as your... whatever we are, I know better.
I say again, why wouldn't you have detected an extra sailor aboard?
Because I had no reason to look. And if I did look, I would make use of any extras I found.
Assuming you knew which was which.
A moot question, for there have been no extras since my little art project.
Surcouf, that means we lost our other stowaway! Maybe even a Morgana sleeper. You didn't see fit to tell me that?
It is best not to let your enemy know what you do and do not, non? Best to let them think they are one step ahead of us.
Because they are!
And they will act accordingly, and they will make mistakes.
Besides, our little roll call problem has solved itself in the meantime, non?
It's stepped obligingly out of the way of another.
@BATTLE
I know that look, Capitaine.
Well, you're not the cause of it this time.
Oh, hell.
That headline... "Thief Sailor Detained, Claims Belle Allegiance?"
You knew this would happen eventually.
Oui, and I was not concerned about it. His word against mine, non?
His word is that you trained him to steal INPF cargo and sell it on the black market.
Absurde. I cannot answer for the actions of a common thief. And my record is impeccable.
Do you recognize him, at least? You never forget a face.
... Hmm. Not from our crew.
That wasn't the simple "no" I was hoping for.
I spoke to him once in port, but he was not one of ours.

Fields.MenuText: So he's just looking for attention.
*Whose* was he?
What about?

Fields.DialogueText: Business.
What business?
None of your business.
Some bootlegger. The who is less important to me than the what.
Ugh. So now we've got questions from the Royal Australian Navy to fend off *and* a security leak you seem determined to ignore.
A fatal flaw in a criminal.
Says the submarine.
Who goes about underwater.
One can patch a leak or make a decorative fountain of it.
Surcouf, listen to me. I don't know what you're up to and why, but I will find out. And when I do, you're going to wish I'd dry-docked you on the second of September.
Capitaine, dear Capitaine... what an exquisite present you've chosen to give me.
A threat?
A challenge. And on the eve of battle... you really do love me.
@BATTLE
The picture of courtesy.
That means not pickpocketing them.
Are you being polite to the journalists?
Not even politely?
Stealing from someone isn't polite.
You must think me a common criminal.

Fields.MenuText: I think you've never met anyone you didn't think you could steal from.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, if we are dealing in hypotheticals, oui.

Fields.MenuText: There's nothing common about you.
Well, if the high-heeled flipper fits...

Fields.DialogueText: I wear a 6.5, whenever you're feeling generous.
I have known this since I awoke, oui. Do try to outpace me.
I suppose those have to be custom made.
Who but a Belle could pull them off?
Well, you were right.
I do love it when you talk dirty to me.
It's your word against our newspaper criminal's. He's nowhere near the first to try and claim a Belle made him do it.
Credit where it is due, we are persuasive sorts.
Right, but even so--
*BOOM*
What the hell was tha-- gah!
Down!
Secondary explosions, Capitaine. One never knows.
We need to find out what the hell that was.
Oui, in a moment.
Tertiary explosions?
Morganas, but were it not for them...
@BATTLE
You're lying on top of me.
Was it about their appalling lack of security?
Something like that. That bomber completely blindsided them.
I just had the most exhausting conversation with the port authority.

And they don't even have guards patrol in pairs. They might as well 
*hand* me their wallets.
It must be so galling not to be the only outlaw in town.
Well, on that subject...

Fields.MenuText: Don't tell me you have a sister.
What could you possibly say to make this more complicated?
Don't tell me the bomber was one of yours.

Fields.DialogueText: Even if I did, I wouldn't share you with her.
I constantly ask myself that. You should try it. It keeps conversations from growing stale.
Not one of mine, Capitaine. But not so very far removed.
Non, you see, I got a look at the unfortunate corpse of our unfortunate saboteur.
I recognized a certain tattoo on his right shoulder. What was left of it, en tout cas.
Gangster?
Low-level. I'd had limited dealings with his organization, but found they weren't ambitious enough for my tastes.
Apparently, so did he.
Capitaine?
That's what I was about to tell you.
They got a look at some of the fragments of the device he detonated.
One of the guards cut himself on a piece and it turned necrotic right away.
Disease.
At best, one disturbed individual got his hands on her stuff. But can you imagine a crime syndicate throwing in with the Morganas?
Why, think of the opportunities!
Surcouf, no.
Oui, oui, oui, you need not fear me turning traitor. But that is how they think. They give up some of their humanity to reap a reward from humanity itself.
We can't fight the Morganas at sea *and* on land.
Non. But we can make the humans come to us.
One by one.
It is working for us Belles so far, non?
@BATTLE
Oh, dear. It would seem that my crew and the Australians are having some disagreements.
They're not the only ones. I got a real testy letter from Victoria Barracks about your personnel burden.
Hey! Go easy!
Did I decide to triple security in Australia's ports, Capitaine?

Fields.MenuText: I'd say you were involved.
Yeah, I asked them pretty much the same thing.
More marks for you, right?

Fields.DialogueText: On what grounds? That a mad bomber sought to make a Constitution of me?
Flattering as the attention is, even the comfiest cuffs may eventually chafe.
Wrong, Capitaine. I have greater ambitions than simple larceny.
Someone was looking for an excuse to turn a sharper eye on you. It isn't exactly a secret that petty crime tends to increase when you're in port.
But it sure is fun.
Not the point.
There's more at stake here than just our safety, unfortunately.
Some call it the Belle Effect. People turn out in droves to see us, Capitaine. And in every crowd there are a few opportunists.
No, there is not.
Just for a moment, pretend you care about other people.
Continuez.
I flipped through some papers lying around. There was a weapons bust in Auckland a couple weeks back.
And I was not invited?
They caught a guy who brought some evil gun to a bar fight.
Can a weapon truly be evil?
When it's grafted itself to someone's hand, it's at least inconvenient.
Anyway, there were mug shots. Same tattoo as our guy in Sydney.
Hmm. I do not believe in coincidence, Capitaine. I conduct brisk business among those who do.
One organization has turned its back on me. Bien. There are still those who have not.
We still don't have proof. And we are not involving ourselves in a gang war.
Non, we are not. But there is no reason I cannot put my ear to the ground.
Should I be-- no. I'm going to be on my guard no matter what.
In my line of work, we call that "step one."
@BATTLE
You need not lose sleep to come to that conclusion. I did not.
You don't sleep.
Hawera Star... Sydney Morning Herald... Daily Telegraph...
Damn it. This can't be a coincidence.
You should try it.
You know that's not possible.
Neither can I leave the ship, and yet Mademoiselle Wichita has made a valiant effort.
Laws can be broken, Capitaine. Even laws of nature.
So I'm learning. There's more than just our incidents in Sydney and Auckland.
With the same organization?
In most cases. They haven't exactly kept a tight lid on whatever guns they've been running.
Ah, discipline. Unfortunately necessary, though I personally strive to avoid it.
Well, most of these guys are out of control. Lacked the discipline to keep their mouths shut or their Morg weapons holstered.
We will find them in due time.

Fields.MenuText: Cavalier as ever.
Setting thieves to catch thieves?
We'd better. I can only imagine if one of these things gets into a crowd.

Fields.DialogueText: On the battlefield, it is indeed a virtue to remain mounted.
These incidents are drawing unwelcome scrutiny to the underworld, Capitaine. There are plenty who would like to see these upstarts stop starting up.
It would indeed be bad for business.
Upstarts stop starting...
You know what I mean.
Well, I've spent long enough on this. I think I'll grab myself a--
You wouldn't prefer *I* grab you?
Hmm? Oh--
Morganas to our left, criminals to our right... I fear we have had so little time to ourselves, Capitaine. Why not seize this moment?
Surcouf...
Capitaine...
... What are you up to?
I cannot indulge my baser desires without suspicion?
I heard that door lock just now.
A little privacy never hurt anyone.
Uh-huh. And what happened to "He can watch?"
*ALARM*
Do button your shirt, Capitaine. It's unbecoming to stride into battle all mussed.
@BATTLE
Marine.
M-Miss Surcouf!
Be an angel and handle one more mail delivery, won't you? There may or may not be something the Captain is expecting. Look for a box with this address... here.
R-right away!
Of all the lousy--
Capitaine! Why, what a delight to see you here. And so bold. There are dangerous types about these days.

Fields.MenuText: We've got some unfinished business.

Fields.DialogueText: Do we ever. Shall we find some crates conveniently placed?

Fields.MenuText: I'm speaking to one.
Keeping Feldman out of trouble?

Fields.DialogueText: You flatterer, Capitaine. It'll get you seduced in your quarters while you search for clues one day.
There's something that just doesn't add up.
Yesterday's delivery went off without a hitch, yes?
Package present and accounted for!
Perpetually.
Ah, never you mind, Capitaine. I am nothing if not a fastidious bookkeeper.
Not our budget. We haven't had an unusual Morgana encounter lately.
Beyond the usual inconvenience.
Australia doesn't know anything. But we haven't had a discrepancy in our briefing on the area since... since that first one.
That only one, Capitaine.
It's like they're laying low.
It is as I tell the crew, Capitaine. A habit is a dangerous thing to keep.
Why, if I were a Morgana, I would give you a week to recover, perhaps two, before--
*BOOM*
Mon Dieu!
Another bomb!?
From over... oh, mon Dieu.
*ALARM*
The port has personnel enough. We've got a bigger problem.
@BATTLE
All her worldly possessions... such as they were.
She traveled light?
Is that the last of it?
Not even worth the usual five-finger passage fee.

Fields.MenuText: You steal from the crew?
How far you've fallen from your black-market dealings.
I suppose I should be thankful I only lose the occasional handful of jelly beans.

Fields.DialogueText: It is only theft if nothing is left behind. They give the occasional franc in trade for valuable lessons in security.
One does not wait until the Olympics to train, Capitaine.
Your tastes *are* improving.
Wait... what's that?
What is what?
In among the clothes there. I swear I've seen that symbol before.
Why, Capitaine, what have we here?
Haven't we seen this on the mad bomber?
And those other unfortunate miscreants. Capitaine... perhaps Matelot Feldman was not as hapless as she liked to appear.
This *is* her handwriting.
But in some incomprehensible language. Perhaps a cipher.
It's too perfect.
Oui, perhaps one problem has solved another.
Surcouf!
Oui, oui, oui, I will have this code broken inside of the calendar week.
Morganas now, code later.
@BATTLE
Many a delightful thing, Capitaine. I have counted no less than three covert couples among the crew. Two of them share.

Fields.MenuText: That's... exactly what I didn't mean.

Fields.DialogueText: What have we found out?
Oui, Feldman kept her whole diary in this mysterious cipher. Gossip and all.
Anything useful?
I have determined that she is not the spy we thought she was.
But the symbol--
Was a simple reminder of the trail she had stumbled across.
Capitaine, you really should learn this code for yourself. She has drawn connections from the mail and the papers that even I had failed to draw.
Like sailing through a haunted lagoon, is it not?

Fields.MenuText: ... Like, with you, or--
That's not our business any more than it was Feldman's.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine! I am more territorial than that.
And that was a warning, by the way.
I wasn't--
Bien. Back to business.
Well, there's something I hadn't been aware of.
You don't say.
You don't read the mail.
Not since I improved the communiques, but perhaps I ought to. We might have uncovered this whole business sooner.
No hope of uncovering that sleeper on the crew, then.
Long gone, Capitaine. And Matelot Feldman's investigation is enough to clear her.
It is even enough to trace orders and addresses higher than the low-level thugs we know from the bars and bombs.
Perfect. We'll turn all this in and--
Non, Capitaine. We will let slip only what the authorities need to know. And that involves tracking down the letters Feldman copied out.
The letters she *what?*
She was a little like a Morgana, Capitaine. Like me. Too much time on her hands.
And sometimes that fosters terrible habits.
@BATTLE
Litigate the proclivities of the dead later, Capitaine.
Are we due for any unpleasant surprises, Capitaine?
If you're right about the Morgana sleeper being gone, I suppose so. Though we wouldn't know if we were.
You will learn to appreciate uncertainty as I do, Capitaine. Another word for it is opportunity.

Fields.MenuText: The opportunity to lie, cheat, and steal.

Fields.DialogueText: An unfair world must be made unfair in one's favor.

Fields.MenuText: The opportunity to get blindsided and killed, maybe.

Fields.DialogueText: You will never win this war without taking risks.
I'm told that's what you do when you're behind.
What a risk the Morganas took crossing here from another dimension, non?

Fields.MenuText: The opportunity for questionable decisions.

Fields.DialogueText: If a decision is not questionable, is it even a decision?
What else would it be?
An instinct, mon très cher Capitaine.
We're short on time. Have you found the letters we need?
I have been moving them to my wine vault, where they will be safe.
I'd almost forgotten you had one of those.
See that you do not. I thrive on envy.
@BATTLE
Weather. Weather. Letter to a sweetheart. Weather.
Were these not in chronological order?
Whatever filing system Feldman had, I expect it made sense only to her.
Wait... I think I've found something.
"The following was decoded from the original, cf. the cipher on Page 417..."
"I remain astonished that this treasure should have found its way to Australia, and in such capable hands..."
Capitaine, if I may--
"... but the complement and size of Madame Surcouf is such that I feel confident that certain guests will be tolerated, to say nothing of her unique character."
It seems you have found the next question, Capitaine.
Those of them that moved your present, oui.
And those that weren't?
So the stowaways were your doing?
Susceptible to threats.
Let me get this straight. You've allowed me to jump through all these hoops getting our crew straight? And you knew this whole time who was who?
Do you interrupt *my* irrational ambitions?

Fields.MenuText: I ought to.
Not for lack of trying.
I'm surprised you self-describe as irrational.

Fields.DialogueText: And hold me back from my full potential?
What *exactly* do you mean by that?
Why, whatever I like. That is why it is called potential and not destiny.
You see, Capitaine? Where would you be if I did not drive you to strive so?
Sleeping a lot better.
Oh, don't pretend you don't enjoy it.
For now, Capitaine. When I am free, perhaps your world will think differently.
So the guns... Feldman... what was it all for?
You, Capitaine.
Me?
I'd wanted your gift to be a surprise, but it seems that that was not in the cards.
That treasure the letter was referring to...
If you do not want it, Capitaine, I am of course happy to sell it. You would not believe what I had to go through to acquire it.
I actually might, Surcouf. But once we're in safe waters, we need to have a long discussion about personnel.
We will have it over a sumptuous dinner within the week, Capitaine. That is the other half of your present.
@BATTLE
Good news for a change?
Well, this is a relief.
"Arrests Made in Connection with Morgana Arms Trade."

Fields.MenuText: Don't worry, they're not talking about you.
I can't shake the feeling that this isn't over.
That ought to let us relax a bit in port.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, but they are, Capitaine. You've fallen right into my trap. I am none other than the Morgana Deception.
That's going to stop being funny the minute we meet her.
Oui, and then I will kill her and it will be hilarious.
Perhaps the head of the snake has been struck off, but who knows where the eggs are laid?
It ought to let my crew relax. They do not handle patrols nearly as well as I do.
Well, regardless. They busted a major smuggling ring and at least shut down importation.
Thanks to a tip from a mysterious benefactor.
I can't believe you didn't want to come forward publicly.
Capitaine, surely you do not mean such a silly thing.
I'm serious. You're already famous for dodging that bombing attempt. Think of the goodwill you could get by personally taking down the people behind it.
And then my name would be mud with those organizations with which I would prefer to maintain a working relationship.
You can't hide in the shadows forever, Surcouf.
One day I may not have to.
Because the rest of the world will be as corrupt as you are?
Allegedly.
That might be farther off than you think. If I were a crime boss, I'd be laying low.
One must always be laying low, Capitaine. Leave the conspicuous consumption to those who have bent the law to their selfish ends.
After all, why bend the world to your will when you could bedevil someone else's?
Ask the Morganas.
Perhaps I shall, Capitaine. You would be surprised at what one can learn even from one's uglier sisters.
@BATTLE
Try the duck, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Do I want to know how much this cost?
You can have the meat. I'm still working on the breadfruit salad.

Fields.DialogueText: I had to do something with the spoils from Tahiti. Such as they were.
What would you do with the information even if you did, Capitaine?
One of these days I'm going to have an answer, and you won't be prepared.
Adaptation beats preparation every time.

Fields.MenuText: Delicious. You cooked this?

Fields.DialogueText: I trust nobody but myself with such an occasion. Imagine the temptation for a poisoner.
Can you even be poisoned?
Not, I suspect, in any way familiar to humans.
I've got to hand it to you, Surcouf. You sure know how to give a gift.
A dinner fit for an empereur, eaten under your new Matisse...
How in the world did you--
Shh. Just bask in the wealth.
@BATTLE
Never say no to a post-action bite.
These skirmishes have a way of working up an appetite.
I hope you're hungry, Capitaine. What I have planned tonight will live in the memory of your mouth through the end of the war!
You're not basking.
I'm trying. It's just...
It's not right.
I thought I'd taken careful notes on your tastes from your diary.
Not that. We're down a sailor, the Morganas might still be trading with human criminals elsewhere, we've got a security problem, and here we are eating like it's our last meal.
I always believe every meal might be my last, Capitaine. One savors it more that way.
Feldman will be honored and remembered for the dutiful woman she was. If a touch scatterbrained.
And nobody enters or leaves this vessel without my knowledge or control.
Even the Morgana sleeper?
Especially the Morgana sleeper.
You said that a habit is a dangerous thing to have.
We are expected to root out the enemy, Capitaine, not to adapt to her. The Morganas would find some new way to infiltrate me if I destroyed their man on the inside.
But that doesn't make sense. Why wouldn't they keep feeding the Morganas information? Why wouldn't we be constantly under attack?
Perhaps their tattoo was bothering them.
... You're not serious.
People *can* serve two masters, Capitaine. Sometimes even three.
Morgana technology is tantalizing treasure for any thief. And where better to get it from than someone on the front lines?
How much?
Never enough, Capitaine. Never enough.
So it was you all along?
It frequently is.
You slipped the Morgana weapons to the smuggler ring?
Networking, Capitaine, networking. I simply found out who our sleeper was working for and beat Disease's offer.
I expect they are living like a king somewhere very far inland, where double-crossed Morganas cannot find them.
All for the low, low price of our patrol route.
What sort of Belle would I be if I could not handle the occasional ambush?

Fields.MenuText: Maybe one that doesn't deal with Morganas!
An ambush that you set up!
Surcouf, what you're saying is treason.

Fields.DialogueText: What are you going to do? Have me executed?
I am never off guard if I know when I am to be caught off guard.
Think of the strategy, Capitaine, and you may leave tactics to moi.
You could have gotten us all killed!
I am already dead, Capitaine.
My strategy is to defeat the Morganas, not to bring them onto land!
If the war spills over into your human countries, Capitaine, would you not prefer it be on human terms?
Those terms are written in human blood!
I rust, I rupture, I run out of diesel. Any moment could spell my end.
And that is if I do not win the war and live out my days as a motionless museum ship. Or in a scrapyard.
Shall I not wrest whatever emancipation I might from the time you humans have rented to me?
And if one of us happens to get onto your trail? You'll blow them up too, like you blew up Feldman?
Feldman was an accident. The tragedy for you is that the government bonds I sent her to retrieve perished in the explosion.
Is that what we are to you? Accidents?
You are a happy accident, Capitaine.
Who else has managed to catch me off my guard?
Who else may command me?
And oui, I am not blind to my sins. So who but my equal could forgive them?
Not that I have anything to forgive. But you humans insist on judging Belles by such standards.
Could you live with yourself if I sank to the bottom of the sea… unforgiven?
That's your business. Granting forgiveness or not is my business.
And you take your business seriously. Seriously enough to hunt for and read through weeks of hand-copied letters.
... Too seriously.
Come to bed, Capitaine. While the Morganas sleep. We will think on the sacrifices we must make.
Not all sacrifices are created equal, Surcouf.
Nor all Belles. Nor all humans. That is the ordinary way of your ordinary world.
One escapes it by being extraordinary.
That's one word for it.
I had fallen out of their favor, Capitaine, and they had fallen out of mine.
It is the nature of Morganas to harm humanity, Capitaine. Once that organization turned to Morgana arms, there was no turning back.
The Australian authorities snipped that loose end for me and for the world, as far as humanity is concerned. You are better off without collaborators.
Collaborators that *you* created.
You are the capitaine for a reason, Capitaine. You will find many others.
